Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: So much, wow: basically the class is focused on vector calculus and linear algebra, but the first half of 230 you basically get a crash course to all of math. And you learn how to write proofs of all sorts.
Proof writing, basic understanding of math (topology, algebra, linear algebra, calculus)

This course is only nominally a multivariable and linear course -- the heart of it is learning how to write rigorous proofs, which are then used to "build up" to calc/linear content (so you start the semester with a list of things that are assumed to be true about the real numbers, and end the semester having proven major theorems such as MVT). Zero knowledge of writing proofs beforehand is required; I myself came into it with no experience but now feel much more comfortable with my ability as a mathematician.

I learned about the beauty of mathematics. This class is a calculus, analysis, linear algebra, and proof based class all in one. There is a lot of material in the course, but the class itself is well worth it.

Pat taught me how to do real math. He showed me that mathematics involves thinking critically about a problem, proving new facts from previous facts. Mathematics is not a rote memorization and application of formulas, it is a process of creation and of giving thoughts and ideas structure. I developed skills in proof writing through different areas of math, including topology, analysis, calculus, and linear algebra. This class exposed me to a lot of new math, and it show me how exciting and communal doing math can be.

This course taught how to partake in real mathematics. It taught how to think and solve questions when there is no clear procedure to do so. It is an amazing class to broaden one's perspective and open one's mind.

All of the mathematical structures and content developed in class were new to me. I learned proof writing, analytical thinking, and of course the foundations of vector calculus and linear algebra to a deeper degree than I have ever experienced in a math course before.

I developed a much greater understanding of linear algebra and vector calculus (the name of the course is very accurate). I also discovered much more about the basics of all sorts of math, as well as cool insights into seemingly unrelated areas.

Despite going into the class thinking I knew all I needed to know about Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra, every single day taught me something new. Building up each of the disciplines from the beginning, the course led us on a journey through analysis, algebra, discrete math, topology, set theory, and more. Problem sets were hard, but each problem helped to develop problem solving and proof writing skills, and the collaborative aspect of the class taught me how to work on math with other people. This isn't a course on Vector Calc and Lin Alg - its a course on creative thinking and mathematical rigor, wrapped up with fun puzzles, problems, and games. You'll learn more than you ever wanted to know about limits, derivatives, and vectors, but you'll come out feeling stronger than you'd ever thought you'd feel about math.
A variety of topics from real analysis to linear algebra with an emphasis on proofs.
I learned how to do proofs and greatly practiced my problem solving skills. I got an incredible understanding of math and how everything is interconnected.

Taught basic proof methods and strengthened my proof-writing ability through repetition, application. This course gave me a taste of several branches of math: discrete, real analysis, topology. We did a lot with linear algebra in the second half of the semester. More than anything, this course taught me to expect a higher level of rigor from myself and my teachers. I think about math in a different and better way now.
I began to learn how to write a mathematical proof (not totally there yet), how actual math works, and some analysis and linear algebra.
I learn a lot about how to construct and communicate proofs. It was a very interesting introduction to Analysis and Linear Algebra.
Got a good understanding of proof based linear algebra/single variable calculus that is useful for future math courses.

I learned a lot about calculus and linear algebra stripped to the basics. Having already learned about linear algebra and multivariable calculus before taking this course, I already knew some of the topics covered in this class, but in 230, we took it a step further and proved theorems/postulates/things I just took for granted and showed how they all tie together.

The course taught a lot about various mathematical concepts in a variety of fields, from real analysis and linear algebra to vector calculus. It also gives students many, many opportunities to practice their proof-writing.

Lots! How to prove things logically, and how to wrap my head around things I don't know. Sounds lame, but I also learned how to push through some difficult tasks and how to ask for help when I needed it.
I continued to develop my proof writing skills, and gained a lot of exposure to various fields in mathematics which was an intellectual stimulating and enjoyable experience.
The biggest part of the course is the proof-writing, but we did intro linear algebra, analysis, and calculus, as well as random bits of number theory and combinatorics and a bit of topology.

I learned how to write better proofs! I'm still not great but I feel like I grew a lot and got better at figuring out how to put my mathematical hunches and intuitions into actual words that make sense. I also learned how to think more creatively when approaching problems that require unconventional methods. Now, a lot of solutions that previously seemed so unexpected to me are much clearer and I am getting closer to figuring out those on my own with the help of lots of friends and the TFs!
I learned how to use creativity to solve proofs and I learned so much about math that I'd never thought of before. But mostly the creative problem solving thing

I gained an overview of topics in math including analysis (limits, continuity, Bolzano-Weierstrass), vector calculus (derivatives), and linear algebra (linear transformations, row reduction, determinants, wedge products). What really helped me deepen my understanding of these concepts was that we proved many of the theorems relating to these concepts ourselves on the problem sets, instead of simply being presented with the proof in lecture. As a result, I felt that I not only gained conceptual understanding from this course, but I also developed an ability to reason logically and rigorously through problems, which is a skill that is valuable both in mathematics and many other fields.
The course gave a great introduction to analysis and linear algebra.
Proof writing skills, some real analysis and topology, quite a bit of linear algebra, and a little bit in other random fields of math like algebra
All sorts of math.
I didn't know how to write proofs before taking this course, so it was a great introduction to formal maths.
Basic intro to analysis and linear algebra
I learned how to write mathematical proofs and how to work through seemingly impossible problems.
How to write proofs for mathematics and how to understand linear algebra and multivariable calculus and numbers differently.

I developed mathematical proof writing skills by taking this course. Furthermore, I gained a deeper understanding of the underlying concepts of math, as well as insights on mathematical logic and problem-solving.

Most valuably, a strengthened mathematical thinking muscle, exercised by both the topics we covered and the fun Putnam problems sprinkled throughout Psets. I'd say this course showed me, more than anything had before, what it is exactly that mathematicians do. It's much more than accumulating and learning to use the various math tools we've been exposed to before (like addition, algebra, and integrals) - it's a way of cleverly knowing when to apply these tools.

I learned a lot in terms of proof-writing and critical thinking. This class was unlike any math class I've taken before, and although the content was challenging, I find that I've improved a lot more than I expected I would.

During this course, I learned the core tenets of mathematics, including how to construct a proof, and the basics of algebra, analysis, topology and number theory. Using these tools, I built the foundations of calculus, and linear algebra over abstract fields, as well as a few interesting side ventures into combinatorics and modular arithmetic.
Having come in with very little knowledge of proof-based mathematics, I learned so much in this course exploring areas across the discipline as well as solidifying my foundation in it.
Familiarity with proof based mathematics, real analysis, topologies, linear algebra; a sterner spirit
mathematical thinking. some linear algebra stuff. some vector calculus with a flavor different from that of A-levels.

I have improved my ability to write proofs and think critically immensely. I have also developed an increased awareness of many different areas of mathematics, while also strengthening the understanding that I have for the mathematics that I already know.
I loved this course. Its rigorous but engaging construction of the basis of mathematics up to linear algebra has made me fallen in love with math.
So much proofs. So much. Seriously, this is intro to proving things, and my brain is working hard to learn this mostly new skill.
Lots of math, some critical thinking, and working without making progress for hours at a time.
Logical, rigorous reasoning and proof-writing for mathematics.
Writing formal proofs, thinking mathematically, basics of calculus and linear algebra from the fundamentals
I was able to learn many different aspects of math. It was interesting how different theorems helped to prove another theorem.
I learned about the work involved in pure maths and was able to decide whether I want to become a math major
I acquired a solid foundation in proof based math, especially in topics of analysis, linear algebra, and some topology.

I learned about analysis topics such as sequences, limits, convergence, continuity, closed and open sets, and Bolzano-Weierstrass. Further, we learned some basic linear algebra over general fields and proved the rank-nullity theorem. I also improved my mathematical problem-solving skills and LaTeX skills by typesetting every pset.

I learned about the process of writing a proof, engaging with math formally, developing mathematical insight. On a more practical level, math 230 gives you a solid foundation in multi and linear to take harder math.
I learnt to write proofs, and most importantly, to find flaws in logical arguments

How to think mathematically and appreciate math and proofs in a way thats more theoretical than practical + a lot of persistence and learning to push through struggle without being discouraged

(and calc/lin alg and spatterings of other random concepts)
I got a much better understanding of proofs and linear algebra.
A great insight into what creativity looks like in mathematics.
I have learned skills in writing mathematical proofs.
I learned so much from this course, but the material was very tough.
This course allows you to refine your knowledge of calculus AB and introduce you to analysis, mathematical fields, and linear algebra. It also develops proof-writing skills.

I learned so much during this class that its hard to put it all down. To start, I feel like I learned the basics of many different forms of mathematics, namely topology, analysis, vector calculus, combinatorics, and linear algebra. Furthermore, I learned many different proof strategies for each of these topics, allowing me to think more critically about math than I ever have before. But I think the most important skills I learned related to collaboration with my peers, which was essential in completing the problem sets to the best of my ability. With over 20 hours per week spent on these problem sets, I also learned how to manage a heavy workload and how hard work can make a class feel more rewarding.
Learned about the foundation of mathematics, how to write proofs, and that anyone can do math.
Proofs, writing proofs, mathematical logic, proof techniques, linear algebra, analysis, topology
I learned a lot of fundamentals in linear algebra, but mostly gained a comprehensive understanding of proof-based mathematics.
How to write proofs and many other skills useful for advanced mathematics.
Developed a variety of knowledge pertaining to linear algebra, multivariable calculus, analysis, and topology. Developed proof-writing skills

I learned how to prove things! Yay. And some linear algebra, important theorems, modular arithmetic, abstract algebra, and other funny little math trinkets. I learned how to to problem sets with others and ask for help from peer tutors and Pat, frequently.

I developed a lot of proof writing skills in this course and a different way to think about and solve math problems. The course helped develop my logic and was a very different math course than anything I took in high school, which was what I wanted when I picked this course at the beginning of the semester.
I was introduced to proof writing in addition to some linear algebra and multivariable calculus skills. Analysis techniques were also introduced.
How to write proofs. How to work on hard problems for a long period of time.

One taught me MATH/
One taught me MATRICES/
And one taught me PROOF/
Now, I'm so amazing/
First half of the course/
I've learned math is so fun/
So, look what I got/
Look what you taught me/
And for that, I say/
Calculus/
I'm so fuckin grateful for this math (no, really, i've learned a lot about vector calculus, as evidenced in the next section)

Strengths: the class was literally perfect. 

Weaknesses: none, unless you dont like math. At which point the very high workload would be one.

Love the community and teacher. Pset-based learning is good. Math lounge and pizza are always cool too. I wish there was a official list of theorems/topics though for times I've skipped class and gotten completely lost.

Your skill - not knowledge, but actual skill - as a mathematician will be forced to increase as a result of taking this class, unless you're one of the few students coming into Yale with an exceedingly strong competition math background (and even then, the class would still be worth taking). A prospective student in this class should be aware that problem sets take 10-15 hours (sometimes more), and are often designed to require collaborative effort due to sheer difficulty. Consequently, the class can feel overwhelming at the beginning of the semester. Nonetheless, most students settle into a comfortable rhythm within a few weeks and the class is definitely manageable.
This class is very hard at times, and the professor understand this. He and his TA's were as helpful as possible, and tried to make everyone believe they belonged in the class.

Math 230 exposes students to lots of areas of math while still teaching the core material of proof writing, calculus, and linear algebra. Sometimes the course moves too quickly for students not used to proof-based math, but this is more of a learning curve for the student than a weakness of the course.

I looked forward to this course every day since classes began. As far as I am concerned, there are no immediate improvements to be made. The only possible suggestion I could make is to move the location of the class to a large auditorium so that several hundred students can take it.

The professor and TA's are extremely approachable -- as in they are practically ever-present in the math lounge, which has been critical to our learning as most of our content and skills are learned through p-sets. The course material is also accessible to people like me who do not have a strong math background but learn to think logically rather than rely on algorithmic skills.
Math 230 would be an excellent model for other introductory mathematics courses, as its problem-solving methods seem more conducive to retention and engagement than standard evaluative classes.

The course is very strong in its structure, in that there are weekly problem sets without fail and the professor moves continuously from one lecture to another. The variety of course material presented is also a strength, and besides the core areas the course also provided useful and interesting forays into varied areas of mathematics. 
However, there are also certain weaknesses. Notably, the course felt somewhat too fast at times and relied too little on student input. Some lecture days would just go by with little student participation at all and were mildly dull. Though I understand class size is a limiting factor, it felt like the course leaned too much on the professor's natural enthusiasm for math and not enough on the course's inherently interesting material and structure. Perhaps more inter-student discussion could be used to make the course better.
No weaknesses at all. Pat's incredible engagement and love for learning and teaching makes this course perfect the way it is.
This course has a ton of office hours and builds a great community. Pat is magnificent.

Strengths: Pat is awesome, and Piazza is helpful 
Weakness: material is unorganized sometimes

The professor is incredibly engaging and encourages everyone to continue in the course even though it is a hard course. His lectures were sufficient for learning (I never needed to review or read from textbook) and incredibly funny. He was very often during the TAs office hours and  gave us extra help and advice. There is no weakness I can find for this course.

Strengths:
The problem sets were very well-designed. They forced us to work collaboratively (or at least they forced me to) and regularly had us prove results we would later use. They were the reason I felt so intimately acquainted with the material.
The curriculum was excellent. The course jumped all over the place, but everything we did was part of a natural progression and turned out to be important later on.
Grading system. The problem sets were a good level of difficulty higher than the tests, which I prefer greatly in such a demanding course.

Weaknesses:
This is relatively minor, but the pace of lessons could be extremely variable. At times we would introduce several new concepts rapidly, while other times we would spend an entire class on a proof that I'm confident most students could have worked out themselves.

Strengths: Pat is amazing, you learn so much, you discover what you are capable of, you get hooked on math.
Weaknesses: Not really any, to be honest. I sometimes wish the graders gave more feedback on the stylistic part of our psets, but that is hard, and there are a lot of psets to grade, so I'll graciously cut them some slack.

Its a wonderful excellent course with lots of support from teachers, and Pat is the best. The pace is fast, so perhaps it could be slowed down slightly, but the onslaught of material is also what makes it really challenging and engaging.

Class is taught very well and problem sets are interesting, but lecture goes very slow and the examples are pretty easy. Also the exams are too easy and don't give you a feel for how you are doing in the class - they could be harder and given a curve.
I loved this class taught by Pat. We learned so much about not only the course material but also took mini digressions to explore math as a field.

The course goes over information efficiently and extremely well; through the teacher's highly capable instruction, students go through a lot of material, but  the course offers a lot of support as well. The course is overall amazing, but there remains trouble for those who want to leave after 230, as that puts them in an awkward position within the math department.
There were many topics that weren't fully integrated or "wrapped up" by the end of the course, so maybe these could be molded into a coherent narrative.

The course was quite strong in its coverage of multiple fields of math and rigorous derivations of multivariable calculus and linear algebra from scratch. There was definitely an emphasis of depth and rigorous understanding over breadth of topics, which is a fair tradeoff even though it felt like we didn't cover much compared to linear algebra courses taught in a more conventional setting. And of course, Pat is a phenomenal professor, which I'm sure all students can agree with. The course felt weak in its reliance for students of less talent/experience in mathematical thinking on help outside of the classroom at the math lounge, which I definitely took advantage of since I always felt stuck and reliant on others for help. I found myself spending an entire afternoon/evening doing problem sets, which was expected but felt defeating at times knowing that other students didn't need to.

Strengths: Pat is fun, curriculum is very entertaining, environment is very supportive.

Weaknesses: lectures could stand to be more organized and more importantly a lot faster (in my opinion). The class is a bit too big, meaning the level is far too high for some and far too low for others.

The community and support that's built organically in the class (with the help of Pat and the TFs of course) are what got me through a lot of tough concepts that I definitely couldn't have navigated alone. Now I'm convinced that friendship is the real secret to learning a lot! Making friends was the best part of this class and I don't think I could've had a better time doing math than with all of the amazing and supportive folks I met on this journey. If you read this Pat, please keep on facilitating this sort of warm and welcoming community in math, and thank you so much for encouraging all of us to try our best together instead of upholding the more traditional exclusivity and elitism that used to take all the fun out of math for me.
On a slight tangent, having extensions on p-sets was incredibly helpful just because of how much time they take and how assignments from other classes sometimes all get inconveniently assigned in clusters.

The strength is in the professor. He teaches the course with great enthusiasm and is really helpful to struggling students. The weakness is the difficulty of the problem sets, often needing students to look to others who'd already solved the problems

The strength of this course is definitely in the problem sets. Pat does a wonderful job of putting together just the right mix of problems -- both fundamental theorems and Putnam-style problems that develop creativity and ingenuity. They challenge students who have seen the material before while still managing to be accessible to those encountering proofs for the first time. 

On the other hand, I did not feel that I gained as much from the lectures. I felt that Pat could have covered the material at a faster rate and presented proofs at a higher level of rigor. I also feel that the logical flow of the course could have been organized so that new concepts were better motivated; for example, we could have defined the determinant and used that to motivate the definition of wedge products instead of working with wedge products first.
The course did a great job splitting between development of ideas in lecture and practicing and discovering new concepts individually in problem sets.

Strengths: A truly challenging course that tests your ability to write proofs - I think it's a great intro course for people who are considering the math major or just generally like math
Weaknesses: Lots of work - psets are long but sometimes that's the fun of it, also there could variance on pset graders

Strength: Psets were interesting and engaging
Weakness: Probably could have had more practical numerical examples in Problem sets (they aren't that difficult to add on considering how much work the rest of the Problem set is). Also, it's kinda weird to collaborate with people on problem sets.

The workload/time investment for the course is very high if you don't have much background in formal mathematics (not necessarily a bad thing, but a lot of time was spent on psets). The upside is that Pat is an incredible instructor and is very understanding of his students. He does his best to make sure every student is doing well in his class, so grades aren't really a concern. He also encourages a lot of collaboration and is really trying to create a math community - something I appreciate a lot.
It either needs to be optional or needs to be taught at a more rapid pace - as it stands, it is too slow for the more experienced people in the class.
I think the strength is that the class doesn't have a certain area of focus, which made it possible for the professor to meander and address the areas in fields other than linear algebra.

The strengths of this course are that it is intellectually challenging and that it helps to broaden one's understanding of what math truly is, and it could be improved by including more examples of proofs from which we can base our own written proofs off of.

+ Engagement with lots of math (and lots of very fun math).
          Though the psets were as arduous as rumored, I definitely appreciated how they force one to grapple with the problems.
- Though we became good at answering specifically phrased questions, we could have gotten better at *asking* our own questions. This would force even deeper engagement with the concepts.
          I'd love a long-standing bonus that rewards students for inventing a problem and solving it. We can, of course, do this without prompting, but with such a heavy workload makes it hard to find time for such an occasion.

+ Material was covered in an engaging, memorable way.
+ The exams were never stressful.
The class is very well organized and assignments while difficult very interesting. The workload is extremely high, so the class can be very stressful, but it's enjoyable as a whole.

This course had truly exceptional lectures, which supplemented a challenging series of problem sets used to prove the concepts central to mathematics. Rarely did I feel like there was much that could be improved, although there was a lot of work.

The greatest strength of the class was definitely the supportive environment. The great deal of office hours, the fact that the class was not curved, the ability to collaborate with others on PSETs, and Pat's overall enthusiasm fostered this environment. However, one of the weaknesses of the course was the threat of imposter syndrome. The class was difficult because everyone came in at different skill levels with some people catching on to the pace level and amount and difficulty of the course load at different times. The lectures were a strength in this area because they were very accessible. I do wish we had conquered some of the more challenging proofs or concepts covered on the PSETs in class because then I would have felt more prepared on PSETs and had a better foundation to make self-discoveries. Yet, these are all minor things because truly the supportive structure of the course ensures anyone's success if they put forth the effort.
The course is excellent in its current form, with great community ethos and collaboration

strengths: general thinking skill rather than familiarity with any particular techniques
weaknesses: you do not get to learn the content that well

This course is effective at teaching how to actually do mathematics. The problem sets are difficult, but give a real sense of accomplishment and are learning experiences themselves. The course does go fast, but this is a strength for the quantitatively-minded student. The course is well-organized for learning, and students finish the semester feeling like they have learned a lot of mathematics.
This course is very fun, but can be intimidating and discouraging at points, although very rewarding once you start to understand the topic.
No weakness. Only strength. This course is bloody fantastic, and should be done exactly as it is.

Pat is great at helping and explaining when you ask, so YOU SHOULD ASK if you don't understand things. The course material can be out of sync with other courses taught on Analysis or Lin. Alg. so there are limited online resources to help which can be a little frustrating if you don't understand something or want an alternative motivation/explanation.
I would like the pace of in-class learning to be slightly faster.

Strengths: very rigorous and thorough, exams are very fair and do not deviate from the material.

Weaknesses: problem sets were sometimes a little tedious
The professor is very passionate in math and the overall atmosphere of the course was very energetic and positive.
The course has an excellent support network, more than any other class Ive seen, but still found it difficult to find enough support in the hardest moments in the class.

One of the biggest strengths of this course is that it is an indicator of whether the math major (or proof based math in general) is right for you. It teaches you how to battle through hours of pset problems and emerge feeling like you have become a better problem solver and thinker. The weaknesses are probably that the lectures can sometimes feel a little scattered, and there is often a good deal of thinking and time that needs to be put in to realize how the psets connect to what's being done in class (and sometimes this connection doesn't exist).

This class has an unparalleled community and support system - the Piazza notes and question forums allowed students to ask and answer other students' questions and share class materials and practice exam questions. If every other class could use Piazza, then the learning environment would strengthen exponentially. The only weakness this class had is that psets were sometimes not graded in a timely manner, but that's understandable, considering the volume of psets that had to be graded.

Math 230 was a fantastic introduction to college-level pure math. Not only does Pat teach you how to write a proof and formally interact with math content, but also gives you appropriate foundation in multi and linear to take more difficult math, making for an ideal foundation for any STEM major. The only downside is the workload, but the rewards are well worth the effort.
The professor was very engaging, and an extremely good set of notes was provided by fellow students.

Honestly dont see any weaknesses. Strengths are that its an amazingly encoursging environment even for the students that may not have as strong of a math background (read: didnt grow up doing math since they were out of the womb) and inspires students to appreciate and engage the subject without putting too much of an emphasis on grades
The lectures were engaging and the material was challenging.
Lots of learning at a very fast rate.

Strength: the course enables me to challenge myself and attempt interesting problems
Weakness: therere no sample solutions to psets
The workload is very high with problem sets taking from 15-25 hours and due weekly, but it very effectively develops the skills necessary for higher math courses.

The strengths of this class were the engaging and easy-to-understand lectures, the informative problem sets, the general curriculum, and the overall spirit of collaboration and learning. The only weakness was the stress caused by the heavy workload and potential impostor syndrome caused by such a difficult class with such smart people; however, the incredible instructor made large efforts to reduce these problems.
It moves very fast for students who haven't had experience with proofs before, but other than that it was really good.

Strengths: engaging, appropriate level of rigor, collaborative and not graded on a curve

Weaknesses: none

The course is pretty rigorous so a major strength is how much it motivates you to learn. The PSETs are very difficult and really required that students attend office hours, collaborate, and spend their free time thinking about the problems. At the same time however, the difficulty of the PSETs is also a weakness in that students with a less extensive math background might find the concepts very intimidating and may feel alienated at times.

strengths: organized curriculum, good lessons, well written and evaluated exams.

weaknesses: little correlation with any textbook, large and varying workload every week.
Super thorough course, no real weaknesses

Strengths: the professor (Pat), the peer tutors, the free cookies every 4pm in the math lounge, the content (I think it's pretty good for an intro math class), Friday pset due dates (cuz you rarely have any other work due that day), class notes online, piazza, MATH LOUNGE, oh did I mention Pat?, pat's cat pictures, working on the psets in the math lounge
Weaknesses: 9:25 (though it'll be 11:35 next term), a fair amount of people don't go to lecture sometimes, walking back to Old Campus from the math lounge at 3am and it's really dark and quiet (but it's a great space), sometimes doing a p-set without really understanding it cuz you're working with friends (but then when you're studying for the final you look over and thinks sink in a little more). Sometimes I wonder if I really understand what I'm doing or not.

Strengths include the collaborative environment, the support received from a myriad of resources (peers, peer tutors, the instructor, piazza page, etc.), and the intellectual challenge of the course. Not really any weaknesses besides the amount of time spent doing psets (10-15 hours a week).

One of the strengths of the course is that I feel that office hours, TF, and other students are all great resources for collaboration. I think one of the weaknesses tended to be the length of work sometimes (however that is the design of the class).
Sometimes seems to go slower in class then on the problem sets. I would like more lectures like the sphere cube game, odd town, sperners lemma, etc.

If youre at all interested in math, shop it. Its a good class to help you determine whether or not you actually like it. If you do like math, absolutely take it. Its a lot of work but its manageable, worth it, and often times enjoyable. There are so many ways to get help, and collaboration is explicitly encouraged.
Yes. If you like math at all, take this. You don't need experience with vector calculus.
Absolutely. Anyone who is seriously considering math at Yale should take this course at hesitation. There is truly no comparable alternative.

I definitely would. If you are interested in majoring in mathematics, or seeing what it is like to work on proof-based math, this class is definitely worth it. Everyone deals with academic struggles in this class, so the difficulty of it should not be a reason to not take the class.

I would recommend this course to another student iff that student has a passion for mathematics. This class has a very high workload, but it is incredibly rewarding and insightful for people who like math. For students who hate math, this class would be a whirlwind of new symbols and vocabulary, and none of the connections would have meaning. However, for students who enjoy mathematics, this class provides a beautiful and intricate basis for any future study in mathematics.

I would recommend this course to anyone with the slightest interest in math. If you are willing to put in the work (which is a lot), you will broaden your mind in so many ways. If you are deciding between this class and MATH 120, take 230! If still on the fence, I would strongly suggest sitting in on this class the first day; you will figure out very quickly if you like the way this course is taught. I decided within the first five minutes sitting in this course that I needed to take it; I can honestly and without exaggeration say that was one of the best decisions I have ever made.

Yes -- the only caveat is that the workload and level of engagement required are intense. All work is generally worth the effort, but whether a given student can afford to expend that effort depends on the rest of their schedule and interests.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Despite the few flaws I spoke of, it was challenging, exciting, spontaneous, and rarely truly dull. I won't lie and say that the course was easy -- it has the reputation of requiring a lot of work and definitely lives up to that reputation. However, the material covered and the general enthusiasm of all my fellow students made the class absolutely worthwhile and enjoyable. Recommended without reservations.

Take this course, especially if you want to know whether or not math is 'your thing.' Pat will be there for you, help you feel more confident in your abilities, and show you that you can do it. Yes, it's a pretty tough class, even if you have a strong background, but every day is so worth it.

I took this course as my sort of trial by fire for Math at Yale. However, I think the class serves as more of a trial by campfire: maybe you'll get a little smoky, maybe you'll get burnt a little, but no matter what you'll have a great time and eat lots of s'mores.

Pat is an amazing professor and this class is truly a community; it's filled with entertaining and interesting people who are all in the same position as you. If you want to take a class where you know you will learn a lot, this is the one for you. There is also a ton of support, Pat is a very merciful overlord, there are tons of office hours throughout the week, and working on PSets with a huge group on Thursday night is kinda fun. Also, the tests aren't bad if you just memorize the theorems which you use throughout the PSets anyways.

It's a lot of work, but it's a lot of work with friends, so it's really not that much work at all.
Yes, it is a great introduction to proof-based math
Definitely. The course ends up being easier than lower numbered courses because of how helpful the professor is. Also, it is the perfect course for any math major.

Absolutely, I would recommend this course to any student who enjoys math or who thinks they might. It fundamentally changed the way that I think about and learn math, plus it let me dip my toes into all kinds of different fields of math. I can already tell that after taking 231 I'll have a much better idea of what courses I want to pursue after this, and I'll be equipped for any of them.

Yes, if they might be interested in math and have plenty of time in their schedule, do it. Expect to spend hours upon hours cranking out psets in the math lounge, with its distinctive musty-armchair smell (the most disturbing part is that, after some time, you begin to enjoy it). Expect to struggle quite a bit, and expect to spend some late nights questioning yourself, but also expect to find yourself beginning to enjoy it, finding friends to do psets with, and gaining a lot of self-confidence as a thinker and mathematician. This class was a great decision, and I would highly recommend you take it.
Yes! This is a wonderful course that makes abstract and dense material very approachable and accessible. The homework is extremely fun and the lectures are very clear and interesting.

Would recommend if student is interested in pursuing math or maybe physics and is willing to put in time, don't take if you're doing engineering or something like that because you won't actually learn how to do computations - it is entirely proof based. May also be too hard unless you have a good math background.
Yes.
I would totally recommend this course with Pat. If you like math, and don't mind proofs, this course is wonderful.

Yes! This course is normally recommended to prospective math majors, but I also think it'd be useful for any major that is driven by logical argument. Writing, philosophy, sociology, history could all benefit to varying lengths from this course. It's an investment because of how many hours it takes up, but it is definitely worth it.

Would definitely recommend to students with background in competition math, proof writing/math research. Even for someone who had done competition math like me, it was still a worthwhile struggle to grind through the problem sets. Anyone with less experience than that, though, I felt would have to be willing to allocate significantly more time than even I did, which feels almost unreasonable for a single course.

Yes, but if they're math majors I would also recommend adding another course on top of it. Particularly for freshmen coming in with a strong math background, just 230 might not be enough (and it's easy to screw yourself over by taking only 230 first semester and then finding out most second semester courses are parts of sequences that began in the fall).
Yes!!! Even if you don't plan to major in math, this class will help you gain a much deeper appreciation for math on its own, as opposed to a tool that's only useful once applied to other things.
I would only recommend this class to students wanting a challenge with something new or aspiring math majors. It is very fun but super difficult

Yes! I would not only recommend this course to math majors (for whom it is required), but anyone interested in developing stronger logical thinking and problem solving skills. While the style of the problem sets may initially seem intimidating to people who have never done proofs before, there is so much support from teaching assistants, fellow students, and Pat himself that anyone who is willing to put in the work can succeed. If anything, the course taught me that mathematical ability is not something that people are born with; it is something that anyone can develop given enough dedication.

If you like math, you are doing yourself a disservice by not taking this course - the heart of math is proofs and this course is the best way to train that skill. It also covers the important topic areas that you need to know as well, but just through proofs.
YES! Math 230 has the potential to be the quintessential Yale Math Course.

Yes!! But, only if you're interested in math and have have the time to make this course a priority (this also depends on the person, I'm sure some students did not need to spend quite as much time on this course as I did). I think I've grown a lot as a student through the challenges I faced while taking this class, and of course, it's always worth it to take a course with Pat.
If they are interested in a light intro to proof-based math, I might.
Yes, but I would only recommend it to someone who is willing to put a lot of time into the course and has a lot of grit.
I believe that this course really improves your mathematics skills, although the rigor is something that should be seriously considered.
Yes. For students interested in math this is a great course to establish a foundation in math.

I would recommend this course to another student who really enjoys math and who is up for an intellectual challenge. This is so because this class is a lot of work, but it is very fulfilling at the end.

If you have an abiding love of math - or have ever felt the hint of one - this is a class you cannot miss. No other first-year selection will involve you so intimately with math's beauty.
Elsewhere, you can learn how to operate mathematical tools: how long-division works, what functions are, how to integrate. This functional relationship is likely all you've ever had with the subject in the past 12 years of school. 230, however, transcends this bricklaying to make you a mathematical architect. Is it hard? Most definitely. The workload will take a good chunk out of each week - it will cut severely into your Netflix time - but you'll make friends with this fact (literally), recognizing that this sort of intensity is precisely why you came to Yale.
The teaching is amazing. The community is welcoming. The endeavour is unsurpassable.
I would recommend this class to other students because even though it is challenging, it is very enjoyable and lectures are interesting.
If you are at all interested in math, this course is for you. An excellent introduction to the Yale math department.

I definitely would, but I would warn them that the work load is great and the time commitment high. However, if they are willing to work hard out of a love for the discipline, it is wonderful community both inside and outside of the classroom to be a part of as a first year.

Yes, to any well prepared first year considering a quantitative education at Yale - the sheer challenge of this course is offset beautifully by the amount of support from the Professor, TAs, and fellow students, making the journey a rewarding one.
yes if you are not interested in memorizing integrals involving tangent substitutions and drawing graphs in 3d.

I would absolutely recommend this course. It is very well done. However, the course goes fast and relies on a rock-solid conceptual understanding of mathematics, so a student without time to dedicate to the 10-15 hour problem sets or with a less strong mathematical background should think before taking it.

Even if you don't think you love math, or don't think you have a strong work ethic, take this anyway. These things can be developed, and this course provided one of the most fun and rewarding ways to do so.

HELLLLLL YEAH
THIS WAS THE BEST COURSE I HAVE EVER TAKEN BY AN ORDER OF MAGNITUDE.

If you want proof based math then yes. The amount of time I spent on this course varied pretty dramatically week to week, but on the top end (as I'm sure the other reviews say) it could be quite a bit, though on average it was very manageable.
Definitely.

Definitely - lectures were nice and easy to follow, problem sets were a bit difficult but definitely helped in learning the material, exams were fair and reflected the material well, feedback was detailed and helpful.
Yes, because students get to learn math in a very cooperative and fun environment.
Not universally, but I would tell them its a great course to take if you think youre interested, even if it was not the right class for me.

If you take the class knowing what you are getting yourself into (20 hr/week psets, plenty of long, long nights in the math lounge, etc etc), and you are still excited about the class, then yes, I would recommend it. It is a good indicator of whether the math major is right for you, and beyond that, you will become a better problem solver and feel much more confident in your math abilities. However, it is very important to seriously consider the time commitment this class is -- it will essentially make all your other classes that semester take a back seat, so keep that in mind. If you're willing to dedicate your life to math for a semester (and usually 2 because it is natural and expected to take 231 the following semester), then take this class.

Yes! This class is a great introduction to math at Yale and allows you to form a network of friends with whom you will spend many hours working on psets or chatting about life. Plus, Pat's awesome - can't pass up an opportunity to hang out with Pat.

Absolutely. Math 230 is a fantastic introduction to pure mathematics, and is a must-take if you are interested in mathematics. Despite the high work-load and difficulty of the class, Pat does a great job making the class approachable and accepting of all students, regardless of previous math experience. I would highly recommend this class to any student considering a math major; if not, while the class is tremendously rewarding, your time may be better spent elsewhere.
This course is very interesting, and I would recommend it to anyone considering the mathematics major.
I love this course. It was very difficult but very rewarding. I would highly recommend it.
Yes!! 100% if you are interested in understanding math as an abstract concept (not calculations because you dont do too many of those) and are willing to put in work
Yes, if they want to put a lot of work into math and be rewarded for it.
Definitely, anyone looking to make new friends and really get a taste of math.
Yes because we all love Pat!

Unless you feel confident or excited about math, I wouldn't recommend this course. However, if you do find yourself struggling, please go ask for help! Everyone was very helpful and constructive when solving problem sets.
This coures is great for any math majors. Otherwise, the workload might be too high.

I would recommend this course to any student who really loves math and is willing to work very hard. While the workload sometimes feels overwhelming, if you really like the material the class is engaging enough to overcome any difficulties. However, if you are unsure about working hard or loving math, I would be very wary because it could become a real time sink and drag to your semester.
It depends, it is useful for math majors and hard science majors maybe, but not for engineers or people not interested in math.
Yes--the course is incredibly engaging and the support structure is very nice--but you must be willing to dedicate a lot of time on problem sets.

I would say that this is a course you should only take if you truly love math. It's very intensive so if you don't enjoy the subject then your experience in the course will be extremely stressful and unpleasant. For those who love math and have had experience with proof-writing, this course will be very fun and engaging.
Yes! It's great to learn proofs, especially from Pat.

Definitely, especially if the student is interested in math. It's takes time, but it's not too difficult. It's really well managed and run by Pat (I mean basically the class is great because Pat is great), and the resources like Piazza, class notes online, and p-sets help you to learn the stuff. It's a pretty social class (a lot of students gather regularly in the math lounge) so that's fun. The peer tutors are really fun to work with. You'll make friends through the struggle.

Yes! If you liked math in high school and was pretty good at it and want to experience proof-based math or some higher level math, then this is the course for you! It's a lot of work but it's definitely worth it because you end up learning so much and getting a different perspective on math itself.

If you are interested in pursuing math in any capacity or are just curious about what college level math is I highly recommend this course. I found that this course not only helped me to become a better math students but also a better thinker. This course offers an introduction to mathematical proof writing and exploration into linear algebra and multivariable calculus, this is not an easy course by any stretch of the imagination and every student will struggle in their own way. Even though I found that I routinely struggled I believe that I truly benefitted from the course and the community that is fostered by the course. I confident as mathematical thinker and proof writer and even though it took me some time to build that confidence, I credit that to the course and the challenges a long the way. Office hours fosters a welcoming community and the availability of TAs/TFs/Professor was incredibly generous. The only reason and situation I would not advocate taking this course is if you are already taking a heavy course load. The weekly Problems sets can be a lot sometimes and for most students they require anywhere from 3-20+ hours a week, if you think you might be on the higher end of that spectrum as well as plan on taking several heavy work load classes, shop the class and get a feel before committing.
If they really like math and proofs.

I can't tell enough people to TAKE MATH CLASSES (like this one, and Math 225 by Asher) if you've had a bad experience with math before (say, in high school) or think it isn't for you ("I'm not good at math", "I haven't really done calculus before, and vector calculus AND (?!) linear algebra seems intimidating"). Please give it a try. Puppies are counting on you (that is one argument they did NOT make in "Green Eggs and Ham"..). OK, FINE. TELL ME ABOUT THE COURSE. Yayyyyy!!!!!!!!!! (Trust me. Pat, if he's teaching it, will be literally at least this excited when you tell him that you're taking the course.) Pat will get you to like math. He will drop your homework assignments, and explain mathematical terminology in conceptually wholesome ways. Make sure you're collaborating with someone you like on the problem sets. https://goo.gl/forms/ltNp5XbZEVI2yHbq1
